content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Search for a hotel in Berlin available for a three-night stay from March 15 to March 18, 2024, for one adult. Tell me the price in USD and CNY for the three-night stay.  Please interact with https://www.booking.com/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I should input the destination "Berlin" into the “Where are you going?” combobox to start the hotel search flow.  
Action: Type [52]; Berlin
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to adjust guest count to 1 adult before setting dates; click travelers button.  
Action: Click [7613]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to reveal the traveler controls (+ / –) for Adults; try scrolling a little inside window to see buttons.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Traveler popover likely located further up near search bar; need to scroll up to view adult count controls.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to reveal the “Adults” +/- controls that are inside the open travelers pop‑over in “Search properties”. I will scroll a bit inside that Search properties area.  
Action: Scroll [6515]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: In the Search properties traveler pop‑over, I don’t yet see the “Adults” plus/minus buttons; I may have scrolled past them. I will scroll that pop‑over upward a bit to reveal the controls.  
Action: Scroll [6515]; up

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to return to the top of the page where the search bar and travelers pop‑over are located so I can change the number of adults to 1. I’ll scroll the main window upward.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to bring the top of the travelers pop‑over (with the Adults +/- buttons) into view, so another upward window scroll should help.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The traveler pop‑over is open inside region 6515, but the +/- controls for Adults aren’t in view. I should scroll inside that Search properties region to reveal them.  
Action: Scroll [6515]; down
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The travelers pop‑over controls are likely above in the Search properties panel; I need to scroll the Search properties region upward to reveal the Adults +/- buttons.  
Action: Scroll [6515]; up

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I’m currently far down the page near the Filters section; I need to return to the very top where the search bar and traveler pop‑over (Adults controls) reside.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I should open the calendar to set the March 15 – 18, 2024 dates.  
Action: Click [7154]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Previous month” arrow of the calendar is probably just above what is currently in view, so a small upward window scroll should expose it.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to expose the top of the calendar pop‑up where the “Previous month” arrow should be; another upward window scroll should bring it into view.  
Action: Scroll WINDOW; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar within tabpanel 15616 likely has hidden top part containing the “Previous month” button; scrolling inside that calendar up should reveal it so I can navigate back to March 2024.  
Action: Scroll [15616]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I will click the “Next month” arrow in the calendar so that the “Previous month” arrow should subsequently appear, letting me navigate back toward March 2024.  
Action: Click [15554]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to navigate back in the calendar toward March 2024; clicking the “Previous month” button will move one month earlier.  
Action: Click [15897]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to keep moving the calendar back toward March 2024, so I’ll click the “Previous month” arrow again.  
Action: Click [15897]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The “Previous month” arrow is likely above the visible part of the calendar. I need to scroll the Calendar panel upward to bring it into view.  
Action: Scroll [15616]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to reach months earlier than April 2025 in the calendar; scrolling the calendar panel upward will bring earlier months like March 2024 into view.  
Action: Scroll [15616]; up
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar panel 15616 is still scrolled downward; I need to scroll that panel upward to bring the “Previous month” button (e.g., March 2024) into view.  
Action: Scroll [15616]; up
